greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The odd part of A340072(n).
comment: Each term a(n) is a multiple of A340149(n), therefore, as both sequences have only positive terms, it follows that if a(n) = 1 then A340149(n) = 1 also, but not necessarily vice versa.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8191
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..65537
Index entries for sequences computed from indices in prime factorization
program: A003961(n) = { my(f = factor(n)); for(i=1, #f~, f[i, 1] = nextprime(f[i, 1]+1)); factorback(f); };
xref: Cf. A000265, A003961, A019565, A339901, A339904, A340072, A340074, A340076 (positions of ones), A340149 (differs from the first time at n=85).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 28 2020
